author: Steve Rosenbloom
title: Extraordinary Joe: Maddon should win Manager of the Year
text:
If you’re scoring at home, that’s Joe Maddon campaigning for Jake Arrieta not just for the Cy Young Award, but also NL MVP this week.
“He’s got to be in that conversation, too,’’ Maddon said of his stopper who is 21-6 with a 1.82 ERA and other ridiculous numbers that cover almost as many years as the Cubs’ World Series futility.
Next, Maddon will spread Arrieta’s Oscar buzz and suggest him as a darkhorse presidential nominee.
Also if you’re scoring at home, that’s Maddon on the stump for Kris Bryant’s worth as Rookie Of the Year and MVP, as well.
“Look at his numbers,’’ Maddon said, and here are those numbers: .279 batting average, 26 homers, 99 RBIs, .865 onbase plus slugging percentage, and a 6.2 wins above replacement, according to Fangraphs.com.
Indeed, Maddon could present strong cases for Arrieta and Bryant, but one thing the Cubs manager can’t publicly declare is that the Cubs manager should be named Manager of the Year.
Somebody ought to declare it, so, here goes, and let’s start with the Cubs record.
Three NL clubs have won at least 93 games, and Maddon’s team is one of them.

(Mark Gonzales) When the year began, did you expect the Cubs to win 90 games?
Did you expect them to have the third-best record in the league?
Did you pick them to earn a playoff spot, not to mention clinching it more than a week before the end of the season?
No chance, no way, no how. Not me, anyway.
Depending the algorithm to which you’ve sworn your analytic allegiance, the Cubs seemed to be pegged for 83 or 84 wins, maybe 85 this year.
So, Maddon’s Cubs surprised the league. The Manager of the Year Award is always about surprises.
And speaking of surprises, Maddon has done the impossible, or at least the unprecedented:
Reaching the playoffs with significant contributions from four rookie position players.
In a piece for Beyond the Boxscore, Scott Lindholm cited the use of Bryant, Kyle Schwarber, Jorge Soler and Addison Russell to validate Maddon as the only manager to orchestrate a playoff team under such circumstances.
Jon Lester yearns for more starts Mark Gonzales After reaching two milestones Wednesday, Jon Lester hoped that his 10-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds wasn't his final start off the 2015 season.

(Mark Gonzales) And when you include Javier Baez, Maddon’s game of toy soldiers evidences his ability to put young players in position to succeed when the players themselves might not know what’s good for them.
Forget the magician in the clubhouse, the petting zoo on the field and the onesies on the plane. What matters is how a team plays, and Maddon coaxed, demanded and worked his own magic to create a team that will play in the postseason for the first time since 2008.
Cardinals manager Mike Matheny deserves respect for managing the best team in baseball despite absences of Adam Wainwright, Matt Holliday, Matt Adams and Yadier Molina.
Pittsburgh’s Clint Hurdle also gets votes for challenging the Cardinals, but both teams were expected to reach the postseason.
Mets manager Terry Collins perhaps stands as Maddon’s closest competitor. The Mets won the NL East without any offense until Yoenis Cespedes was acquired.
But here’s the thing: For most of the season, the NL East had the two worst teams in the league while the Cubs reached the playoffs in a division topped by the two best teams in the majors.
Not just the league. The majors.
I’m not sure what other case needs to be made.
Which leads to this: Theo Epstein brought in and/or developed the plan to produce all that young talent. He also snagged the prospective Manager of the Year. He deserves an award himself.
We’re gonna need a bigger red carpet.
